section-block.rac_essential-question: How can we make things go?

section-block.rac_book_summary: Did you know that everything needs a push or a pull to get moving—including you? This book includes fascinating facts about how things move. It answers many science questions using colorful pictures, and even has an activity for you to try!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Talk with children about how things move, like how to move a toy truck across the floor. What happens when they push or pull something?
Create push and pull verses to the tune of “Row, Row, Row Your Boat:” Push, push, push your cart/Gently through the store/Fill it up with lots of things/Then let’s add some more.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Push and Pull by Cody Crane.
Scout loves reading informational books about how things move. He’s excited to learn about how things need a push or a pull to move.
There is a question I want you to think about as we read. We will talk about it after we finish the book. Ready?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things can move with a push?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do all things need to get moving? Who can show me how you would push a door open?
Now show me how you would pull a door open.
What kinds of things need a bigger push to get them moving?

The children are playing tug-of-war. When people play tug-of-war, two teams work together to pull a rope in different directions. The team that pulls the other team all the way to their side wins. Look at the picture. Can you tell which team will win? How?
What can happen when something that is already moving gets pushed or pulled? (MB)
These two pages are called a glossary. A glossary tells us the meaning of different words in a book. Who can show me the meaning of stopwatch? How did you find it?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things can move with a push?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: A shopping cart can move with a push.
A rocket can move with a push.
Your body can move with a push.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences about how things move as children watch and listen.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can a rocket move with a push or a pull?
A rocket can move with a p_____ (push).
A rocket can move with a push.
What kind of push do heavier things need?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Good social-emotional skills are vital for children to be able to develop important skills such as cooperation, following directions, demonstrating self-control, and working well with others. As you introduce how things move, have children talk to their peers and demonstrate various movements together as they learn about them.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Make Connections
section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss with children how we can look at the connections between pushing and pulling things and how they move. If we push something, it will move away from us. If we pull it, it will move closer to us. What is the connection between the wind blowing and leaves on a tree moving? Will the branches and leaves move faster or slower when the wind is stronger?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit Push and Pull by Cody Crane and look for connections we can make to the story.
Clifford loves to make connections between what he does and how things move. He wants to reread this story with us and look for connections.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book and look for the make connections Mind Builder in action.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How can you get something with wheels rolling? Can you think of something that you see everyday that has wheels? (MB)
Your muscles push and pull your body when you run, swim, and jump. (MB)
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit push and pull Vocabulary Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Can you think of a time when you have to jump?
What makes waves in the ocean? (MB)
Look at the picture of the boy playing baseball. How can you connect what the boy is doing with something that you like to do? (MB)
What kinds of things can you do with a stopwatch? What does a stopwatch measure?
How can a push make a ball go slower or make it stop? Show me how you can stop a ball with a push. (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Distribute some heavy and some light items, such as blocks, paper, or a heavy book, to children. Have them work in groups to practice pushing and pulling the different items across the floor. Have children discuss which objects were easy to push and pull and which were harder.
Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about connections between what people do and how things move.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning about cause and effect begins at a very early age and plays a role in all content areas. Throughout today’s instruction, make sure children understand the connections between what they or others do and how something moves. Encourage children to keep making these connections throughout the week. (Morin/Verywellfamily.com, June 11, 2019)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Discuss how what we already know, or our background knowledge, can help us understand what we read.
Have children sit in a circle. Add a small ball in the middle. Encourage them to think of ways to move the ball without using their hands or feet. Have them take turns.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to revisit Push and Pull by Cody Crane.
Scout knows how some things move from his own experience playing with his toys. He can’t wait to read more information about making things move by pushing and pulling.
This is the guiding question I want you to think about as we read:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things can move with a pull?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Read-Aloud: Focus on Using Background Knowledge
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to pick children to answer questions. Have back-and-forth conversations with children to extend language.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The girl is pushing a shopping cart.
Do you think it’s easy to push a shopping cart? Why?
How do your muscles help your body move? (MB)
Let’s all jump up as high as we can and see what muscles we think are helping us move.
Bumper cars are a kind of ride at amusement parks where you try to bump into other cars. Have you ridden in bumper cars before? What can pushing and pulling help these cars change? (MB)
Friction is a type of pull. What does it help the horse do? When was a time that you used friction to pull something? (MB)

Look at the picture. The pink and yellow books are making a ramp. If you put the car at the top of the yellow book, do you think it will go down fast or slow? Why? How do you think the car will move if we try to make it go up the ramp? (MB)
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What things can move with a pull?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose 2–3 children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Some doors can move with a pull.
Some toy cars can move with a pull.
A wagon can move with a pull.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you work together to write about how we can make things move.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: A wagon can move with a p_____ (pull).
A wagon can move with a pull.
What things can stop moving with a pull?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Establishing background knowledge for multilingual learners is a critical component of their comprehension. U.S. games, holidays, foods, nursery rhymes, and even TV shows and movies may be unfamiliar to some multilingual learners. Check children’s understanding of concepts like bumper cars when reading to children.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion of all they have learned so far this month about how things move. What have they learned that they did not know before?
Give each child a small toy car. Create a ramp using books for some cars. Then have children push their cars and see which one goes the fastest.

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to look at a poster called The Great Big Enormous Yuca. On the poster are pictures that go with the story I will read to you.
Scout loves to look at posters with pictures of people working together.
Push and Pull and The Great Big Enormous Yuca both focus on ways that people can move things. Let’s see if we can find connections between the two.
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show Push and Pull book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: As we read the Big Chart, let’s think about how it connects to this week’s concept question: How can we make things go?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to Making Things Move
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the poster, then use the following prompts to discuss it.
Use Equity Sticks to pick children to answer questions.
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The old man pulled and pulled.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: The yuca was the biggest plant the old man had ever seen. Do you think he can pull it out by himself?
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The old woman pulled the old man.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why is the old woman pulling the old man? Can the old man pull harder with the old woman’s help?
Who can point to the dog? What is the dog doing? Why?
Do you think they will pull up the yuca from the ground? Show me how you would pull a huge plant from the ground!
section.rac_d-hed_page_number: The enormous yuca finally came up!
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What finally helped pull the enormous yuca out of the ground?
Why was it so hard to pull the yuca up? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Choose pairs of children to play tug-of-war with each other. Give each pair a short rope and have them take turns pulling the rope with varying force while the other child holds on. Encourage children to describe what happens the harder they pull.
Provide a writing prompt about how things go and give ongoing feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children develop large motor skills, followed by stability (turning, twisting, balancing) and manipulative (throwing, catching, kicking) motor skills. Gross motor skills require thought and deliberate movement. This includes giving and receiving force from objects.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: LET’S INVESTIGATE | WEEK 4: Make It Move

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to show what they have learned this week and month about how to move objects. Guide them through a series of simple exercises including doing jumping jacks, flapping their arms like they are flying, clapping their hands, moving their arms in circles, and taking giant steps around the classroom.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book Push and Pull by Cody Crane.
This book is an informational text. That means it is based on real facts. Scout loves to learn about and look at pictures of real things in books like this.
This week we read about how things move. As we read the book one more time, I want you to think about this guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can happen when something is moving?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the book together. Use Equity Sticks to pick children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Roller coasters have lots of pushes and pulls. Machines help take the roller coaster cars up the ramp.
Let’s pretend we are on a roller coaster. Stand up and lift your arms in the air. Wheeee!
What happens to the ball when it is hit? Does the motion of the ball change?
Show me how you would swing a bat to hit a ball. (MB)
A stopwatch measures how fast or how slow something is moving. What activity could you time with a stopwatch?
The picture shows a horse using friction to stop. Let’s rub our hands across the table. The friction between your hand and the table makes your hand move slow. (MB)
Look at the boy’s skateboard. What makes it go? Does the ramp help the skateboard go fast or slow down? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to turn and tal k about the guiding question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: What can happen when something is moving?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, pick 2–3 children with Equity Sticks to share.
Possible responses:
Invite children to draw or write about how things move and share their work.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Something can sl_____ (slow) down when it is moving.
Something can slow down when it is moving.
What happens when a car goes down a ramp?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Young children learn about their world by moving their bodies through it. The more children move, the more they feel comfortable and the more they can understand complex concepts. Look for opportunities for children to demonstrate today’s concepts about how things move with their own bodies and by moving with each other.
